The bipartisan infrastructure law is taking steps towards protecting our climate by:
🔌 Building more electric vehicle charging stations
⛏️ Cleaning up old mines + curbing pollution
🚌 Investing in public transportation

1492599827892473856.text: On the anniversary of the founding of the NAACP, I want to honor Ida B. Wells, one of the founders, and a journalist, suffragist, and activist whose writings brought attention to the horrors of lynching, the need for reform in America’s cities, and the indignity of segregation. https://t.co/EysBlVoc1P

1492257136059027459.text: I’ll always have the backs of small business owners – that’s why I’m working on a bipartisan law alongside @SenatorHassan and @SenatorTimScott to reinstate the Employee Retention Tax Credit – a critical benefit that helps cover costs for small businesses.

1492255160621539335.text: Today, I want to briefly highlight some legislation I’ve introduced to close the racial wealth gap – my LIFT Act would help first-time homeowners (predominantly people of color) shorten mortgages and build equity faster. It’s one step we can take towards ending this gap.

1492196742443544581.text: Forced arbitration clauses prevent workers that have been sexually harassed from being able to use all tools to seek justice. Yesterday, we passed a law to end them and allow survivors to bring their claims to court – accomplishing one of the largest workplace reforms in decades.

1492166541231550465.text: This week I got a perfect 100% from the Humane Society for my efforts to support legislation that protects animals. Here’s to another year of meeting pets all across the Commonwealth and passing laws that keep them safe. https://t.co/DIiQkTIbxU

1492142270950346761.text: The bipartisan infrastructure law is an investment in a greener, more accessible future. With this announcement, Virginia can spread more electric vehicle charging stations across the Commonwealth. https://t.co/MvPp74WGkR

1491933080889835534.text: Today I want to highlight Amanda Gorman – the first-ever National Youth Poet Laureate, the inaugural poet, and an activist, author, and speaker. Her poetry speaks for itself: https://t.co/FYWO2vNgG2 https://t.co/Sk1H2cMt8R

1491919836993265669.text: Earlier this week, I got a chance to talk to @Surgeon_General about our bipartisan efforts to pass the DETOUR Act – which would prevent dark patterns from luring you into clicking or subscribing to things you don’t want. It’s time to pass this law and support online transparency. https://t.co/aIdF8kuW9G

1491845068537446407.text: Glad to see @POTUS make a stop in Culpeper today to talk about lowering health care costs – it’s time for Congress to take meaningful action to address lowering prescription drug prices. It isn’t fair that families are spending huge portions of their income on life-saving drugs.

1491807924662018050.text:
I’m pleased the House took action on this – advocating for reforms to USPS has been a top priority for me, and this bill is a step in the right direction towards making USPS run better for all Americans.
https://t.co/cg6DZ1wSsP

1491782587563622402.text:
The bipartisan infrastructure law is the gift that keep on giving… for communities all across Virginia and for the next decade.

This week we announced $22 million to help reclaim and clean up abandoned mine lands across Virginia. https://t.co/EfgyC4gFbF

1491538989689585669.text: Today I want to highlight Maame Biney – a Restonian and an Olympian representing Team USA this week. She was the first Black woman to qualify for the US speedskating team back in 2018 and is competing in Beijing this year. Good luck on your remaining events, Maame! https://t.co/4km9yGwuOb

1491504301394599937.text: Today, as chair of the Intel Committee, I led all our members in a letter to @POTUS urging maximum intelligence sharing with Ukraine. Russia’s threats to Ukraine are a threat to democracies globally, and we must do as much as possible to support Ukraine at this critical moment. https://t.co/FS3RcjopwD

1491487061890719755.text: Glad to see Scott Nathan confirmed as head of @DFCgov – I know he’ll bring a great range of expertise to the role and continue leading the agency as it helps alleviate poverty and support small business owners globally.

1491471963621142528.text: We should honor #BlackHistoryMonth by passing voting rights legislation that meaningfully restores the Voting Rights Act and ensures that Black voters have equal opportunity to cast their vote.

1491441764351111169.text:
I’ll always support our business community here in Virginia, especially during the pandemic. I met with Black-owned business leaders in Arlington last week to discuss how Congress can best continue to support small businesses.
https://t.co/2n861iSjqY

1491418241746763778.text: If you are stuck in a joint consolidation loan that you wish to separate, please reach out to my team: https://t.co/1KOasgGvsw

1491418152286433283.text: Proud to be a champion for student loan borrowers saddled with the debt of their former partners, including survivors of domestic violence. @JohnCornyn, @SenTinaSmith, @Marcorubio, @RepDavidEPrice and I won’t stop until we deliver long-overdue relief by passing this bill into law https://t.co/XjUeDv00Iu

1491172487123456001.text: There are still 6 million unprocessed tax returns from the 2020 filing year. That’s unacceptable, and I’m keeping the pressure on the IRS to do better and get folks their returns.

1491142288231251971.text: This is big news – so many contributed to these efforts and I’m proud we were able to conclude the resettlement of Afghan refugees living in Virginia. https://t.co/lad5gBFlW9

1491119873690587136.text: During #BlackHistoryMonth, it’s also important to continue to speak up about how a history of discriminatory policy has hurt Black Americans – and advocate for change. This article from @BrookingsInst charts and examines the racial wealth gap. https://t.co/nNEGpe69iR

1491081135329361929.text: Last Friday, I headed out to survey a bridge that’s been having problems for months. Thanks to the bipartisan infrastructure law, this bridge – and hundreds just like it, all over the Commonwealth – are going to see improvements. https://t.co/mVydIHkfeY

1491056837386326016.text:
It's important to me to represent all corners of Virginia. This week, we secured some wins for SWVA:
⛏️ $22 million for cleaning up abandoned mines
📍Victims of flooding in Buchanan County will be able to apply for assistance through the SBA

1490834204942389251.text: Today, I want to highlight the contributions of Thurgood Marshall. Prior to his time as a justice, Marshall founded the NAACP Legal Defense Fund and argued the case Brown v. Board of Education in front of SCOTUS. His legacy forever challenged segregation and changed the court. https://t.co/8yqAKzriYw

1490807588505542658.text: ICYMI: our push on accountability for Amtrak worked, and they admitted to critical mistakes during January’s winter storms. But I’ll continue monitoring this, and making sure they continue to do better moving forwards.  https://t.co/LkkN5AojyC

1490732086063362058.text: I appreciated the opportunity to get to join a roundtable of Black-owned businesses last Friday – small business owners contribute so much to the economy and culture of VA, and I am working to make sure they continue getting the federal help necessary to get through the pandemic. https://t.co/MBX6KMRdCe

1490716992046702592.text: Proud to receive a score of a perfect 100% from the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights due to my voting record in this session! Passing legislation that supports and uplifts all communities will always be critical to me.

1490691317621571585.text: I’m no stranger to being around strong women – at home and in Congress. So it was great to get to keep that going by speaking at the AWE Women in Business Summit last Friday and discuss what Congress is working on right now for small business. https://t.co/0C5jxyqG0e

1489986277789286414.text: Incredibly saddened to see another act of gun violence in the Commonwealth this week. My heart is with the people of Blacksburg and the entire Virginia Tech community.

1489736561826713601.text: On her birthday, I want to honor the courage and bravery of Rosa Parks. A passionate advocate and dedicated community member, Parks’ story continued beyond the Montgomery Bus Boycott – she also worked for a congressman and organized for the rights of prisoners. https://t.co/eqmK8XfwBR

1489714900456951819.text: Today, I got to visit the Arlington Ridge Road Bridge – one of the 577 bridges in Virginia in poor condition. Our bipartisan infrastructure law is going to change that, and I’m looking forward to seeing improvements to this bridge and bridges all across VA as a result. https://t.co/gFeQhP51MR

1489691730089680901.text: The infrastructure law is securing major changes for all parts of VA – we’re investing major federal funds on building safer roads and closing the digital divide. This is a transformative, once-in-a-generation law. https://t.co/Z9DDsj0sHX

1489675120826204168.text: ICYMI – there are 577 bridges across the Commonwealth in poor condition – but thanks to the bipartisan infrastructure law, $537 million is coming to VA to change that. No matter where you live, it’ll keep you safer and make travel easier. https://t.co/ieBKAfHkor

1489642617881214976.text: Last week I joined with a few of my colleagues to advocate for this change. This week, it’s happening. Thankful to secure wins that make health care more accessible and affordable during this pandemic. https://t.co/bub2XG7eeu

1489611538415632386.text: I joined @TommyMcFLY to walk a mile together and discuss everything from my bipartisan biking partners to my my favorite spots in Alexandria to my REAL thoughts on @TimKaine… tune in. https://t.co/GdRzwecdOO

1489385467279728646.text: I’m proud of the diplomatic unity our allies have shown as we confront Russia’s armed build-up around Ukraine – we’re using all the tools at our disposal, including a strengthened NATO. Today, I joined CNN to provide an update on our response. https://t.co/Zly1AJ6dxN

1489359289932124160.text: When we passed the infrastructure bill, we secured real improvements for every corner of the Commonwealth – roads, airports, bridges, ports, broadband expansion, and more. It’ll be a decade of real, positive change. https://t.co/sXySB6mRXR

1489330113321840640.text: On the anniversary of the 15th Amendment, I want to pay tribute to one of its greatest advocates, Frederick Douglass. Douglass was an abolitionist, suffragist, and author whose work was incredibly influential in shaping the public and political discussion around abolition. https://t.co/pvsqClcGGr

1489305184131960832.text:
“In fact, [Biden’s] lower-court appointees are arguably more highly qualified… than the judges selected by previous presidents…”
 
Appreciated this data-driven look into the judicial nominees we’ve confirmed so far.
https://t.co/DZfWpOZnIR

1489282533673955333.text: I was moved to read about the victims of the Bridgewater College shooting, Officers Painter and Jefferson. I’m thinking of all those who have been affected by their loss. https://t.co/hESMON99Jn

1489267182731239429.text:
On the anniversary of the ratification of the amendment that gave Black men the right to vote, I’m thinking about the ways our democracy has always needed constant maintenance.
 
I’m still actively working to protect voting rights.

1489260639637970944.text: Glad to see the rollout of the @DHSgov Cyber Safety Review Board. It’s a matter of when, not if, we face another widespread cyber breach that threatens our national security. I look forward to closely monitoring the development of this board.

1489252323943542790.text: ISIS remains a clear global threat, and while any loss of life is tragic, active terrorists need to understand they will be hunted down. I appreciate the bravery of the U.S. forces involved and look forward to getting further briefings. https://t.co/gQvdQVrAsq

1489055580287389698.text: I’m deeply disturbed by the bomb threats against HBCUs — these acts of attempted terror are clear reminders that violent extremism and white supremacy are on the rise. I’ve requested a briefing and remain committed to combatting hate in all its forms.

1488992893712969728.text: Love these Virginia entrepreneurial instincts, the public health amplification, and the fun pitch. Henrico County represent! https://t.co/eWc3QweY8g

1488965452256665601.text:
I’m thinking about my mom on what would have been her 95th birthday. She was an incredible, vibrant, and friendly woman, and she made an indelibly positive effect on all those that knew her. A few years ago, I wrote about her life and how it shaped me.
https://t.co/LNrBUW9VA7 https://t.co/z9Z6NEiJUb

1488940552150265864.text: Already rooting for both of the Washington Commanders. https://t.co/eZa6doj1ri

1488938241457856519.text: Today I want to highlight Maya Angelou, an incredible author, poet, and activist. Her work has challenged, inspired, and moved generations of Americans, and her talents lives on through an enormous, powerful body of work. Enjoy this short poem: https://t.co/7X9xclai8Q https://t.co/4iMv8UlDxV

1488905444005457926.text: Excellent news! The final Afghan refugees living at military bases in Virginia have been successfully resettled! Extending my greatest thanks to all the many individuals and organizations involved. We’ll keep supporting our Afghan allies at a federal level.

1488660672326078467.text:
Incredibly saddened to hear that two officers were killed today at Bridgewater College. My heart is with their families and the entire Bridgewater community. 

Gun violence is a tragic epidemic, so we must move forward intending to do more than just offering thoughts and prayers.

1488594722809651200.text: Continuing to closely monitor the situation at Bridgewater College and am grateful for the efforts of first responders already on the scene. Praying for all involved.

1488572861677809664.text: We’re working through some judicial nominations in the Senate this week. I’m proud that we’ve worked efficiently to confirm some extremely qualified judges – including confirming more public defenders in Biden's first year than the first years of the last 4 presidents combined.

1488547246983548928.text: First up, Mary McLeod Bethune! Among other achievements, Bethune founded several organizations and schools, registered women to vote just after achieving suffrage, served in the FDR Administration and as a VP for the NAACP, and was the only Black woman at the UN founding. https://t.co/nfpMMwztRa

1488547241459695617.text: This #BlackHistoryMonth should remind us that it’s critical to always uplift Black stories, speak up about continued injustice, and celebrate Black history. I’ll be using this thread to do so, follow along below:

1488521044688257032.text: Happy Lunar New Year to all celebrating! May the Year of the Water Tiger usher in prosperity, vitality, and strength for you and your family!

1488273132590796800.text: Access to abortion is a fundamental part of health care. That’s why I’m advocating for a permanent end to the Global Gag Rule and codifying Roe into law by passing the Women’s Health Protection Act.

1488242430281502721.text: Virginia, here’s what the bipartisan infrastructure law has done for you lately: https://t.co/8DjyglaPr8

1488210479130595328.text: I’ve secured $182 million total in federal support over the last year that will directly help Virginians pay for outstanding heating and cooling bills, because I know utilities can be a real strain, especially this time of year.

1488180278560534531.text: Appreciate working alongside a bipartisan group led by @AmyKlobuchar and @ChuckGrassley to achieve commonsense goals and help foster healthy competition in Big Tech. A lot to get done in 2022, and we’re just getting started. https://t.co/IcG60RFU4W

1488157542949732353.text: Today marks the anniversary of the first ever Social Security check being issued – a revolutionary program that’s helped countless American over 8 decades. Alongside @RonWyden @SenBobCasey and others, I’m advocating for improvements to their services and field offices.

1487897401360793603.text: Considering pardoning Jan. 6 rioters is a clear and public endorsement of violence and sedition. This is an abhorrent — but not surprising — statement by 45. https://t.co/AjOJJrCywn

1487183709388345344.text:
ICYMI: VA is getting $20 million to support the eventual construction of 180 wind turbines off the coast of Virginia Beach! I was proud to help advocate for this money, and proud that VA leads on clean energy.
https://t.co/HYVTd5C9ev

1487123306381672452.text: Thinking of all affected by the bridge collapse in Pittsburgh. Investments in our nation’s infrastructure are more critical now than ever.

1487093115777286146.text: The Global Gag Rule prevents health care providers internationally from providing care and services to the most vulnerable. I’m joining my friend @SenatorShaheen in calling for the permanent end of the Mexico City Policy to protect quality care.

1487086252486766594.text: Glad to see this effort from @POTUS, carrying through on our work from the defense bill. There’s much more to be done to tackle this critical issue – we’re going to keep pushing. https://t.co/6LkjqsElV9

1487075860846989317.text: This didn’t just happen – it’s a result of the incredible investment we made in our economy when we passed the American Rescue Plan. https://t.co/kTsWXNWCyw

1486821320574877705.text: The American Rescue Plan just keeps on giving: today, NEA shared its final round of grants for VA as a result of the law. A total of $2.4 million is going to colleges, counties, and organizations for programs that support the arts. It’s yet another win for the Commonwealth.

1486791123846717442.text: I hope 2022 is the year we finally address these questions and create a more equitable internet. https://t.co/bydQWYbc0Z

1486760919820476419.text: 70 million Americans rely on Social Security and Supplemental Security Income, so it’s imperative that they run as smoothly as possible – that’s why I’ve joined a letter to push the Acting Commissioner to address delays and improve service. https://t.co/Pfa9cEfdPR

1486730720500322316.text: On the two-year anniversary of Virginia ratifying the ERA, I’m calling on my colleagues to pass bipartisan legislation to extend the time frame to ratify it. We can’t let an arbitrary deadline stop the progress we’ve made towards this amendment.

1486707314627420161.text:
On International Holocaust Remembrance Day, I’m standing in solidarity with the Jewish community in Virginia and across the United States. 

We must never forget the millions of lives lost and must always remain vigilant against anti-Semitism in all its forms.

1486458930553241600.text: With the bipartisan infrastructure law, we’re unlocking a decade of critical improvements to our roads, bridges, internet service, airports, electric vehicle charging stations, ports, and more. It’s creating American jobs and securing real wins for Virginians.

1486428738099290118.text: Proud to join my friend @SenatorWarnock as he pushes for answers from DoD about a housing contractor that committed fraud. Advocating for military housing has long been a top priority for me, and I’ll continue to try and secure the best conditions I can for our servicemembers. https://t.co/2SVFu8Mbh7

1486425382446321679.text: I’m very grateful to Justice Breyer for his nearly 30 years of service on SCOTUS. His distinguished career serves as a model for all who seek to strengthen democracy. I trust @POTUS will carefully select a replacement, and I look forward to closely reviewing their qualifications.

1486398532512854016.text: I’m not giving up on voting rights. I’m still working to get something done.

1486368337823105024.text: Yesterday I announced $20 million for the Appalachian Development Highway System – which will go directly towards the roads connecting our Appalachian communities to the interstate system. This is a pro-growth move for Appalachia and Virginia.

1486341869680398338.text:
Unemployment in Virginia fell to 3.2% yesterday – another drop and a clear sign of the economic recovery that was made possible by our American Rescue Plan last year. 

I’ll keep voting for policies that get Virginians back to work.

1486097274061131780.text: BREAKING: Virginia is getting $20 million for improvements to roads across Appalachia thanks to the bipartisan infrastructure law! It’s yet another investment in making ALL parts of the Commonwealth safer and more connected. https://t.co/CN0KBU7dGy

1486074497434374144.text:
23% of Virginians are eligible for the Affordable Connectivity Program, a monthly benefit from the bipartisan infrastructure law that makes internet more affordable for Virginians that meet certain economic conditions. Find out if you’re eligible at:
https://t.co/1fsmFGyYuv

1486036149856452610.text: Another win for Virginia: alongside @TimKaine, I’m announcing $2 million for VA orgs that provide housing counseling in the Commonwealth – a set of resources that help tenants & homeowners manage finances and the responsibilities of tenancy to prevent foreclosure or eviction.

1486005949651304454.text: VIRGINIA: if you’re looking for a test, this tool lets you filter by location, pediatric testing, rapid testing, Spanish language, and more. Do your part and get tested when you can. https://t.co/KdtRXvmPOF

1485981222434217988.text:
Climate change is already here, and it’s hurting families in many ways – like bigger utility bills due to more extreme temperatures. 

I’m proud to have voted for $182 million in federal support this year to directly help Virginians pay outstanding heating and cooling bills.

1485734158018260999.text: 2022 is the year we’re finally going to take steps towards meaningful Big Tech reform: promoting competition, leveling the playing field, and making the internet a safer, fairer place.

1485703955950755844.text: Today, I wrote a letter to Secretary of the Treasury and the IRS commissioner to raise concern about the delays some of my constituents have faced receiving their 2020 tax returns. This is an unacceptable delay, and I plan to keep pushing for answers.

1485678600137363461.text: Houthis intentionally firing missiles at civilian targets in UAE is a tactic of terrorists. The UN Security Council should condemn the attacks as such and the Biden administration should explore labeling them as a Foreign Terrorist Organization.

1485673764524335117.text: Every Virginian deserves access to clean water, safe roads and bridges, and affordable, high-speed internet. The bipartisan infrastructure law is making that a reality.

1485658660327936001.text: Appreciate these words from The Virginian-Pilot and the Daily Press’ editorial boards – I’m proud to have secured this transformative funding. https://t.co/sibbhxMMpy https://t.co/APyeVdICL3

1485643557251825674.text: I’m proud to have gotten my bipartisan CHIPS bill through the Senate: it’s an anti-inflation bill, a pro-jobs bill, and a pro-research bill. I’m urging the House to get it done. https://t.co/F7Kkbaf1eK

1484646989207797760.text: Health care workers are heroes, and their mental health matters. We can help by slowing the spread of COVID, and I’m proud that because of ARP funding I voted for, UVA, GMU and VCU are receiving more than $5.5m for initiatives to support health care worker mental health.

1484614390771032067.text: I’m in Richmond today meeting with the Governor’s Broadband Advisory Council. I’ve secured billions in federal support for broadband, and with that plus state investments, we’re on track to being the first state with universal broadband coverage. https://t.co/byEAPo7i8S

1484590820284117001.text: Chuck and I tweet very differently, but we’re collaborating because we share a common goal on this one: helping foster healthy competition in the tech marketplace. https://t.co/XF55oso0Uc

1484556644386177026.text: Americans are broadly united on keeping dark money out of politics – it just makes sense. On its 12th anniversary, I am reaffirming the need to #EndCitizensUnited and restore transparency to campaign finance.

1484530734262071299.text:
Tomorrow marks the anniversary of Roe v. Wade – but access to safe, legal abortion has never been in more danger. 

It’s time to codify Roe and ensure it remains law.

1484261953195462656.text: Our COVID response needs to factor in the needs of ALL communities – that’s why I’m glad the Chickahominy Eastern Division and the Nansemond Indian Nation are receiving over $2 million to support their public health responses.

1484253977634037767.text:
Proud to serve as a cosponsor on this bipartisan initiative to level the playing field for smaller tech businesses and impose sensible regulation on bigger tech companies. 

As a former tech business guy, it’s important to me to work on legislation that helps create competition. https://t.co/2jyZRvT5iI

1484237928394104834.text:
The money from the bipartisan infrastructure law keeps rolling in. This week: $369 million for port and resiliency projects across the Commonwealth.
 
Thanks to this law, we’re keeping Virginia a leader on ports.

1484206243187249160.text: A portion of my statement on the interim CIA assessment on Havana syndrome. You can find my full comments here: https://t.co/P6FFotjZeM https://t.co/jW98Ru3bSN

1484189345431105537.text:
Things that take longer than ordering your free, shipped COVID tests:
🪥Brushing your teeth
📱Solving a Wordle
🐕Walking your dog
 
Take a minute out of your day to take advantage of this great, easy benefit. https://t.co/vbxH3SBmx7

1484006584808259584.text:
The Senate has failed to do its duty and pass even basic voting rights legislation — including a law that passed unanimously in 2006.

I remain committed to fighting for the most foundational American right and preserving our democracy.

1483942126438256640.text: This Monday, I got a chance to meet with and volunteer alongside some resettled Afghan refugees, @USAmbUN, and @LIRSorg. In my role on the Intel Committee and personally, it’s important to me to support all the resettlement efforts across Virginia. https://t.co/UyMkcZCTyd

1483879341100617729.text:
Voting rights isn’t a partisan objective. We made voting easier in Virginia, turnout rose, and a Republican won.
 
I’m fighting for voting rights because it’s the foundation of our democracy – not because I think it favors my party. https://t.co/7b33Nn7CRI

1483865590343213056.text:
When I first got to the Senate, I thought you had to talk to filibuster a bill. But that’s not the case. You can do it without even appearing on the Senate floor.
 
It’s time to make anyone who opposes voting rights legislation explain why on the floor.

1483839167494864901.text: Election Day should be a holiday. The Freedom to Vote Act would make that happen. Let’s get it done.

1483816520891445254.text:
Let me be clear: for decades, reauthorizing the Voting Rights Act was a bipartisan priority.
 
It should be now, too. I’m calling on my colleagues to stop the obstruction and get it done. https://t.co/otpeTUfd26

1483805795095560199.text:
Folks, you’re now able to order free rapid COVID tests (shipping at the end of Jan, courtesy of USPS). Order your tests, tell a friend, and retweet this to get the word out.
https://t.co/XxOCyOTJkk

1483559825665581056.text:
I’m committed to securing benefits for all parts of VA, and I’m proud American Rescue Plan is still bringing money to rural health care providers: as of this week, $130 million to 882 providers across the Commonwealth.
 
Voting yes was a vote for rural health care.

1483529632435654666.text:
Voting rights are essential and preservative of every other right that we have.
 
It’s frankly unacceptable that this issue is being politicized.

1483489163978723332.text: I’m extremely disappointed in FEMA’s decision to deny Individual Assistance to the Hurley community. I will continue to explore ways my office can help the citizens of Buchanan County recover from this natural disaster and mitigate the impact of future significant weather events.

1483476560669810702.text: This is another great tool in our fight against COVID – if you want an at-home rapid test, you’ll be able to order one, shipped for free. https://t.co/qNGDSDpbIV

1483441473823588355.text: ICYMI: last week we announced $537 million in funding for Virginia bridges, thanks to bipartisan infrastructure law. This is a huge investment in making travel around our Commonwealth safer for generations to come.

1483144303316721667.text: MLK Day isn’t about platitudes — it’s about upholding his legacy by fighting for the change he sought. Great to talk about voting rights alongside the Tinner Hill Heritage Foundation and the Falls Church community. https://t.co/8yxfhiL0N1

1483122520320626689.text: Next up on our day of service: meeting with my friend @USAmbUN & @LIRSorg to discuss Afghan resettlement efforts, meet with refugees, and sort some newly donated goods — I’m proud that VA is leading resettlement efforts thanks to incredible orgs like LIRS. https://t.co/zw9aiuuSgb

1483110247610961921.text:
Getting to honor the holiday with service today, starting with delivering some Meals on Wheels with the Alexandria City Council. 

My dad was a MoW driver into his 90s, and I’m glad to carry on the Warner family tradition. https://t.co/c7EuOY3CKp

1483079471930486785.text:
Today, I’m honoring the legacy of Martin Luther King Jr., an incomparable advocate for racial, social, and economic justice.
 
This week, I’ll be honoring his memory with action by voting for the reauthorization of a law he championed – the Voting Rights Act.

1482819369470242822.text: Virginia, there’s still inclement weather on the forecast for tonight into Monday – please stay alert to changing conditions and stay home if you can.

1482420717060771855.text: TODAY is the final day of open enrollment through the Marketplace – if you need coverage for 2022, head to https://t.co/KHkcPCnoFA today to sign up.

1482125377392631812.text: The best thanks we can give healthcare workers is being responsible: wearing masks, getting boosted, and getting tested often.

1482110273750282241.text:
Do you know how much your data is worth to the tech companies that are selling it to advertisers?
 
I think that’s something you have the right to know, and that’s why I’m pushing for laws that will help add more transparency to the ways that tech companies operate.

1482099148262461440.text: Thinking about our cyber defense keeps me up at night, so I just attended a briefing to learn more about the VA General Assembly ransomware attack. 1468587180972990472.text: Ultimately, the goals of the DETOUR Act are simple: instill more transparency in a deceptive online environment, protect kids from addiction, and start holding big tech accountable. I’m looking forward to getting this law done.

1468587176732643329.text: Finally, we know that platforms are not being held accountable for designing to target kids. DETOUR would take the first step towards changing that, making it illegal to use addictive techniques on children under 13. https://t.co/g8MHdvk3uK

1468587111989268481.text: The DETOUR Act would change that by requiring companies like Facebook to get your permission before including you in any psychological test – and prevent them from burying that permission in their general service agreement.

1468587110022197248.text: These deceptions go beyond individual interfaces – manipulation is built into user agreements, too. For years, Facebook has been studying how you are emotionally affected by your feed. It's wrong that they can be doing psychological tests on you without your explicit consent. https://t.co/mTsYaSgfWt

1468587105496543234.text: A lot of these #darkpatterns are merely annoying – but some contain darker implications, like these checkboxes that obscure important privacy permissions. I think you shouldn’t have to struggle to see what data you’re giving away. https://t.co/54EQWIO9eo

1468587101381873668.text: Or one of the most common – have you ever been overwhelmed by popups tricking you into signing up for never ending newsletters? That’s a #darkpattern, too. https://t.co/QD1LyfKBBX

1468587097317597193.text: This #darkpattern really bugs me – can you spot the legitimate download link among all these deceptive ads? I can’t. https://t.co/mFyOyS5F2P

1468587092930600962.text: Or ever been ready to check out and then all of a sudden there’s a range of bogus hidden fees added? Again, a #darkpattern https://t.co/NphgKn1ag7

1468587088903872516.text: So what exactly is a #darkpattern? They range from merely annoying to actively insidious. I’ll take you through it. First, ever had a confusing list of checkboxes that tried to con you into signing up for an email list? That’s one. https://t.co/314dGgbUKC

1468587085103775744.text: Chances are you’ve seen a #darkpattern online – a deceptive internet mechanism used to trap you into clicking, buying, or signing up for something you don’t want. I’m reintroducing a bill to prevent these with @SenatorFischer, @amyklobuchar, and @SenatorJohnThune. https://t.co/tZeJP1Vwpa

1425548139696644103.text: And it rests on our ability to ensure that entities that come into contact w/ that financial infrastructure comply w/ the governance regime we’ve established. We must be clear that innovation/decentralization is not a license to evade the core governance regime the US maintains.

1425548137561735168.text: Our nation’s geopolitical influence – our ability to ensure compliance with AML rules, to combat illicit finance and terrorist financing, is predicated on our nation’s central role in global financial infrastructure.

1425548135951179780.text: But we don’t want to create opportunities for bad actors to evade the sensible and important set of governance rules that we’ve established to ensure that financial networks aren’t enabling illicit activity.

1425548134558670848.text: As a former venture capitalist and someone who’s enthusiastic about innovation, I want to maintain America’s lead in financial innovation, including distributed ledger technologies.

1425548132964786184.text: While that amendment did not pass due to objections, I look forward to continuing to work with my colleagues on this important issue.

1425548131463311369.text: Following robust conversations, I’m pleased to have worked in good faith with my colleagues @SenToomey, @senrobportman , @SenLummis, and @SenatorSinema to reach a compromise amendment that would have memorialized and clarified all of this.

1425548129965838340.text: Ultimately the exact wording describing those validating distributed ledger transactions doesn’t even matter because – again – the Administration & the drafters have made clear to all Senators that validators aren’t covered by the rules under any conceivable consensus mechanism.

1425548128367882241.text: Our amendment *only* mentioned proof of work explicitly because that seemed to be the greatest alarm – based on mischaracterizations and misinterpretations – of the underlying text. @robportman and I revised our amendment to make clear that both miners and stakers aren't covered.

1425548126866313219.text: Some have misinterpreted previous language I had offered to favor proof of work cryptocurrencies – the intent was anything but: to reiterate, all the drafters have repeatedly emphasized they do *not* see validators under any consensus mechanism as subject to compliance.

1425548125301878785.text: Thus, in good faith, I and others worked with Treasury to craft a compromise amendment that sought to dispel those concerns – including making clear to folks expressing concern that miners would not be covered.

1425548123611570185.text: While the Admin had been clear that they would not seek to collect or require information from any entities who could not collect or possess it, we realized that there was clearly a lot of confusion and consternation out there.

1425548121996730370.text:
As @FACTcoalition has emphasized, that clarification from my colleagues was not necessary – and would have hastily and over-broadly carved out DeFi exchanges and custodians, even when they *are* in a position to collect this compliance information.
https://t.co/9KlxYSAVVm

1425548120386068484.text: My colleagues' amendment to the underlying bill would – in the eyes of @FACTcoalition – actually take a step *backwards* in key respects, including (in @FACTcoalition's eyes) undermining the bipartisan AML law Congress enacted law year. https://t.co/MmjLZCMFGb

1425548118871924748.text: To be fair, obscure provisions of tax law aren’t something most Americans have a passing familiarity with. And in an area as complex and fast-moving as digital assets – it benefits all of us to be clear and get things right.

1425548116913176578.text: They’ve made clear the scope of these provisions is limited – and said repeatedly to Senators that it would not capture miners in proof of work contexts, nor validators in proof of stake contexts. Nor would it capture devs simply contributing code to cryptocurrency projects. https://t.co/lpqg1BKrGA

1425548108562317321.text: For over a week, the Administration has reiterated to all Senators involved that the scope of these rules would not extend to parts of the crypto ecosystem where entities wouldn’t in their normal course of business be able to collect the relevant information for tax reporting.

1425548107132059656.text: A bipartisan group of Senators rose to this challenge – clarifying Treasury authority (and ratifying Treasury proposals that have been public since this spring) – in the context of a vitally important and long overdue infrastructure package.

1425548105458593801.text: Second, it’s well-understood that if you pay for something in more than $10,000 cash, there’s a reporting requirement. The bill made clear that this applies to crypto, too, as Treasury had proposed. Even @BlockchainAssn claimed this was common sense https://t.co/U5R8qocw4C

1425548103898308611.text:
As we saw on a different front last week, these decentralized exchanges seek to openly flout the established governance regime the US has sought to maintain.
https://t.co/i4i03yfDMj

1425548102363144192.text: First, we’re seeing decentralized exchanges openly advertise their non-compliance w/ regulatory and tax rules – that’s something that we seek to address in this legislation by making clear that, notwithstanding their claims, they’re still subject to compliance.

1425548100681281541.text:
The tax gap is especially pronounced in two areas: 

1) Cryptocurrency exchanges (some of which openly advertise non-compliance) and custodial wallets, and 

2) Businesses that receive cryptocurrency as payment but don’t report it.

1425548098902843392.text:
First, we need to acknowledge that the innovation and excitement surrounding digital assets has at times obscured some real problems – perhaps none greater than the tax evasion and non-compliance we have continued to see.
https://t.co/P7XHo5Lddm

1425548097220976643.text:
There’s been a tremendous amount of confusion – and in some cases, false information – surrounding a set of important tax compliance provisions in the bipartisan infrastructure package. 

Let’s clear up a few things.

1358933038319689728.text: In this second part of the series, I argue that the U.S. must start investing in American workers. If we are to create an inclusive 21st century economy, we must reform misaligned incentives to boost and ensure public and private investments in workers.

1358933037220831232.text: America’s past economic success was closely tied to our ability to prepare workers for success over their lives and through multiple sectors. Unfortunately, over the past several decades, we have seen a shift in business norms that threatens to leave workers behind.

1358933035983532036.text:
The proposals surround 7 pillars: 
 
1. Boosting Investment in Workers
2. Facilitating Lifelong Learning
3. Investing in Community Colleges
4. Promoting Skilled Workers
5. Funding R&D
6. Improving Human Capital Disclosure
7. Reforming the TAA Program

1358933034821705729.text:
CEOs repeat the adage, "our best asset is our people." To put this into practice in the 21st century, we must realign our incentives to encourage inclusive economic growth.

1334564699392913412.text: In this first part of the series, I argue that we need to create a robust and portable safety net for all Americans, regardless of the type of work they do, how much they make, or how long they have been at a job.

1334564698331738114.text: But, American capitalism no longer holds the promise it once did. If nothing changes following the end of the COVID-19 pandemic and opportunities continue to concentrate for the most privileged, the promise of a robust middle-class life will be out of reach for many Americans.

1334564697492877313.text: We used to get this right. In the 20th century following World War II, America’s entrepreneurial free enterprise system lifted millions of families out of poverty, creating the world’s strongest middle class.

1334564696599498752.text: Today, we see corporation after corporation outsourcing low wage workers – usually without any benefits. In a pandemic, that makes our entire society vulnerable. We need to create a 21st-century social contract.

1334564695756386306.text:
The proposals are organized around 3 central pillars of reforms: 
 
1. Rebuilding the safety net for a 21st century economy. 
2. Reorient priorities to invest more in workers. 
3. Reform our corporate system for a more sustainable form of capitalism.

1334564694384898052.text:
COVID has taken a toll on our society. We’re seeing a rise in permanent job loss, and it’s likely to worsen. For a more resilient economy in the 21st century, we need to shift modern American capitalism's focus. 

Here's the first part of a 3 part series:
https://t.co/kh55jUO21m

1275535666173140992.text:
This is a civil rights issue that is at the core of our democracy. 

The right to vote belongs to the voters, not to politicians. It’s our job to make sure Americans can exercise their rights in a way that is safe and secure.

1275535665405595648.text: Whatever steps that states and localities take, we need to combat the spread of election misinformation by publicizing any changes to voting procedures months in advance of the election, in a variety of languages and formats.

1275535664625389569.text: In Virginia, we have what’s called “curbside voting,” where seniors and people with disabilities can vote from their car. This is another safe and secure way for people to cast their ballots without exposing themselves to coronavirus.

1275535663874682894.text: Similarly, same-day absentee ballots are another way to accommodate and expand access for qualified voters who are trying to safely exercise their right to vote.

1275535663040008194.text:
Let’s start with no-excuse mail-in voting. No matter what misinformation the President spreads about mail-in voting, we know it is safe and secure. 

Registered voters who determine they cannot safely go to the polls should be able to vote by mail. Period.

1275535662209536000.text: At a more basic level, we just need to make it easier to vote. This is not rocket science. We already know what works because many of these policies have been used in both red and blue states for years.

1275535661395836929.text: And rather than closing polling places that don’t comply, we should make sure they are accessible, that poll workers are appropriately trained, and that reasonable accommodations are made.

1275535660749918208.text: Also at particular risk are Americans with disabilities. For starters, any coronavirus-related voting policies should be ADA compliant.

1275535659961405442.text: We know that in almost every state, evidence suggests that Black Americans have been disproportionately affected by the virus. We must prevent COVID-19 from being used as a pretext to suppress the vote in communities of color.

1275535659055362048.text: If states and localities plan to make coronavirus screening part of the voting process, those policies need strong privacy, security, and civil rights protections in place well before election day.

1275535656652025863.text:
We are calling on the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division, @NASSorg, and @NASEDorg to proactively defend the right to vote and prevent policies that could suppress vulnerable and historically disenfranchised voters.

1252617172230254599.text: Based on these findings, there is certainly no reason to doubt that the Russians’ success in 2016 is leading them to try again in 2020, and we must not be caught unprepared.

1252617171282415619.text: The Intelligence Community Assessment represented the kind of unbiased and professional work we expect and require from the intelligence community.

1252617170472833029.text: Finally, the Committee finds the ICA would have benefited from a more comprehensive look at the role of Russian propaganda generated by state-owned platforms in the multi-pronged interference campaign.

1252617169592037378.text: This omission was deliberate, reflecting the well-established norm that the role of the intelligence community is to provide insight and warning to policymakers, not to make policy itself.

1252617168879058949.text: The Committee also finds that the ICA did not include a set of policy recommendations for responding to Russia’s interference attempts.

1252617168056975362.text: Additionally, the ICA makes a clear argument that the manner and aggressiveness of Russia’s election interference was unprecedented.

1252617167108882435.text: We find that the ICA reflects a proper representation of the intelligence collected and that this body of evidence supports the substance and body of the ICA.

1252617166089789442.text: The Committee finds that the ICA presents a coherent and well-constructed intelligence basis for the case that Russia engaged in an attempt to interfere with the 2016 U.S. presidential election.

1252617165099991041.text:
This is our fourth volume of five in the Intel Committee’s investigation of Russia’s attack on our democracy. You can read the full report on the Senate Intelligence Committee’s website, but here are our key findings:
https://t.co/3Da0maLJj1

1252617164198117379.text: The ICA correctly found the Russians interfered in our 2016 election to hurt Secretary Clinton and help the candidacy of Donald Trump. Our review of the highly classified ICA and underlying intelligence found that this and other conclusions were well-supported.

1252617163027951616.text:
Remember the 2017 “ICA” report from the U.S. intelligence community unanimously concluding that Russia interfered in the 2016 election?
 
The Senate Intelligence Committee went back and checked their work. On a bipartisan basis, we found the ICA's conclusions were well-supported. https://t.co/HhbBUz2Kcs

1252596088130940932.text:
I’ve heard this directly from law enforcement and healthcare workers on the front lines in Virginia, and it has got to stop.

1235285568554250240.text:
This $7.8 billion package will make sure the United States has the resources we need to respond to coronavirus. 

In the meantime, it’s on all of us to wash our hands, and follow @CDCgov directions to prevent the virus from spreading.

1235285567094558725.text: I’m glad that we were able to reach a bipartisan deal that was significantly stronger than the original $1.25 billion package the Trump administration requested, and that the legislation preserves crucial CDC funding that the administration has repeatedly tried to slash.

1235285565630828546.text: The legislation also includes additional funding for first responder training, additional beds, and another $100 million for community health centers.

1235285564183785472.text: Fifth, the bill includes language based on my CONNECT for Health Act, which reduces restrictions on the use of telehealth for public health emergency response, as well as $500 million for implementation.

1235285562728292352.text: Fourth, I made sure that the federal government will reimburse states like Virginia for the preparations they’ve already made for the virus.

1235285561742589953.text: Third, I fought for an additional $500M to get the masks, equipment, medication, and other supplies our local hospitals need to be prepared. This will allow @HHSGov to buy these supplies in bulk and distribute them to local providers who need them.

1235285560748658688.text: Second, I helped secure an additional $350 million fund for “hot spots.” We are fortunate that there has not been an outbreak in Virginia, but hot spot funding will let us apply for additional money if one does occur.

1235285559276380160.text: That funding can be used for everything from infection control, lab testing, and surveillance for coronavirus, to contact tracing, mitigation in areas with person-to-person transmission, and other public health preparedness and response activities.

1235285558303354881.text: First, I called for every state to get an immediate surge of cash – Virginia will get a total of $13.3 million. This money will come from @CDCgov and go directly to the Commonwealth’s COVID-19 response through a funding formula.

1235285556835340290.text:
With the threat of COVID-19 Coronavirus growing, I’m relieved the President has agreed to both increased federal funding that I fought for, as well as separate funding for state and local response.

1225440583537364992.text: I hope that the lessons we captured in this report will resonate with lawmakers, national security experts and the American public so that we might be better able to fight off future attacks.

1225440581586911232.text: I am particularly concerned however, that a legitimate fear raised by the Obama Administration – that warning the public of the Russian attack could backfire politically – is still present in our hyper-partisan environment.

1225440580592947201.text: All Americans, particularly those of us in government and public office, must work together to push back on foreign interference in our elections without regard for partisan advantage.

1225440579254935552.text: We also list specific steps the Executive Branch should take to prepare for future attacks, including the development of standing options that can be rapidly executed in the event of a foreign influence campaign, as well as regular, apolitical threat assessments from the DNI.

1225440578164445185.text: Additionally, we recommend an integrated response to cyber events. Rather than treating cyber as an isolated domain separate from other geopolitical considerations, current and future Administrations should view cyber as an integral part of the foreign policy landscape.

1225440576688066561.text: We have also released a number of bipartisan recommendations, including greater U.S. leadership in creating international cyber norms and increased information sharing on foreign influence efforts, both within government and publicly.

1225440575253553154.text: And the Committee found that the decision to limit and delay information sharing about the foreign influence threat inadvertently constrained the Obama Administration’s ability to respond.

1225440574347628545.text: We found the Obama Administration treated cyber and geopolitical aspects of Russia's active measures as separate issues. This bifurcated approach may have prevented the Administration from understanding the full extent of the Russian threat, limiting its ability to respond.

1225440573240348672.text: The Committee found that the Obama Administration was constrained in its response by a number of factors, including the highly politicized environment, concern that public warnings would undermine confidence in the election, and a delay in definitive attribution to Russia.

1225440572065959937.text: The Committee found the U.S. government was not well-postured to counter Russian election interference activity with a full range of readily-available policy options.

1225440570950275075.text: There were many flaws with the U.S. response to the 2016 attack, but it’s worth noting that many of those were due to problems with our own system – problems that can and should be corrected. Our findings include:

1225440569058615297.text:
Today the Senate Intelligence Committee released its bipartisan report on the Obama administration’s response to Russia’s unprecedented interference in our elections on behalf of Donald Trump.
 
Some thoughts:
https://t.co/3MC33VW64Z

1186646637634117633.text:
By putting some basic rules of the road in place, we can preserve your privacy while increasing competition and openness. 

That’s good for consumers. 

It’s good the economy. 

And ultimately, I believe it will be good for the internet.

1186646636086337540.text: We need to put users back in the driver’s seat – controlling their data, the basis on which it’s shared, and with whom it’s shared. If we want to preserve American innovation, we need to lower entry barriers and create space for the next great innovative U.S. networks.

1186646634882654209.text: Long thread, but we’re talking about some fundamental questions about the future of the internet and who our data belongs to.

1186646485355716610.text: But there are services out there that allow users to delegate those responsibilities in a secure way, and our legislation would make sure consumers can take advantage of them.

1186646483833163776.text: If someone wants to manage their privacy settings individually across every single service that has their data, that’s their right.

1186646482813902848.text: Third, we need to preserve delegatability — the idea that consumers should be able to allow a third-party service to manage their privacy settings across multiple platforms.

1186646481408798720.text: By requiring interoperability for major platforms, we can give consumers greater choice over how they access online services like social media, while also preventing companies from using their APIs & terms of service as weapons to shut down potential competitors or extract rents.

1186646479986929664.text: No surprise: it drove online competition and created space for today’s services.

1186646478753800192.text:
Back in 2001, the FCC recognized that interoperability was key to competition and required then-dominant AOL to make its instant messaging service compatible with its competitors. 
https://t.co/vYMj5ShW63

1186646477243850757.text: I promised plain English, so let me give you an example: E-mail is an interoperable service built on open standards. Can you imagine if you were only able to email people with the same email provider? Or if you had to pay a $10/month to email outside your provider?

1186646475662680068.text: So if we really want competition between different providers, we need to go beyond portability and ensure interoperability between different platforms — for messages, cat videos, and the many other types of online content.

1186646474458828800.text: But that also means portability isn't enough if there's nobody to share content or communicate with on a new network or service.

1186646473003405312.text: Social media platforms are governed by a concept called network effects: it means a platform is more valuable — to both the operator and users — the more people are on it.

1186646471422234628.text:
Second, for data portability to really make a difference, we need to break down the anti-competitive barriers that companies put up to limit their competitors from interacting with their platforms. 

This is the idea behind interoperability, the open exchange of information.

1186646470180642816.text: We live in an era where personalization and predictive analytics make the difference between a successful, engaging app and a dull, frustrating app. So users’ ability to port their data – to, in effect, vote with their wallets – can catalyze competition.

1186646468700098560.text:
Is the internet more complicated? Maybe, but with machine-readable formats like CSV, XML, and JSON, the technology is already there. 

The primary barrier is that companies don’t want to ease restrictions that protect their market dominance.

1186646467211079683.text: But sure enough, when Congress mandated local number portability, it drove companies to compete for their customers' business, and consumers benefitted as a result.

1186646465780813825.text: For years, people were reluctant to change phone providers because they didn’t want to lose their number — putting the burden on consumers to circulate new contact info, potentially missing calls from contacts who still had their old number. It was a major switching cost.

1186646464300277761.text:
This would return control of data to users and create new opportunities for competition. 

We know this because we’ve done it before with phone numbers.

1186646462844887040.text: First, consumers ought to have the ability to switch social media platforms and other online services without having to start from scratch. This idea of data portability would allow you to take all your data ~ including your cat videos ~ and move it to a different service.

1186646461406203906.text:
The ACCESS Act has three main components that would apply to the largest tech platforms: 

1. Portability 
2. Interoperability
3. Delegatability

Here’s what that means in plain English:

1186646459992739842.text: To accomplish this, we’ve introduced a bill called the ACCESS Act, which stands for the Augmenting Compatibility and Competition by Enabling Service Switching Act (thank you, bill-naming interns).

1186646458000400384.text: If we want to change that, we need to remove the current barriers to consumer choice and put Americans back in control of their data and their communications.

1186646456553345025.text: American consumers are rightfully growing frustrated with the fact that you have to effectively sign over your private data, in order to use an internet that is mediated largely via a handful of platforms that have come to dominate it.

1186646455001534464.text: For many tech companies, their most valuable asset is Americans’ private data. As a result, the task of defending your online privacy is pretty daunting. Many companies employ byzantine, frequently-changing privacy settings that are often specifically designed against users.

1186646452979802112.text: This is especially true in the digital marketplace, where the unchecked rise of a few dominant tech platforms has undermined users’ ability to meaningfully control their online lives.

1186646451415326724.text:
This legislation is rooted in the idea that competition in the private sector is key to America’s economic success. 

Without it, consumer choice suffers, technological innovation suffers, and America’s global competitiveness suffers.

1186646449456664576.text: This is something I’ve been working on with @HawleyMO and @SenBlumenthal for a while. Today I’m excited to introduce legislation that will put consumers back in the driver’s seat when it comes to digital markets that are dominated by big tech platforms. https://t.co/14ko5k2Ccz

1181617166988263424.text: Bottom line: it is Congress’s responsibility to listen to the warnings of our Intelligence Community and take steps to prevent future attacks from being waged on our own social media platforms. This report provides a roadmap for how we do that going forward.

1181617165528682497.text: Finally, the Committee recommends candidates, campaigns, the media, and other public figures scrutinize sourcing before sharing or promoting new content within their social media networks.

1181617163980988416.text: The Committee also recommends the Executive Branch publicly reinforce the danger of attempted foreign interference in the 2020 election by setting up an interagency task force that can coordinate the federal government’s response to this threat.

1181617162521317379.text: And because information warfare campaigns are waged across a variety of platforms, we also need to encourage greater communication and information sharing between individual companies, government authorities, and law enforcement.

1181617160860454912.text: More fundamentally, we need to give Americans more control over their data and how it’s used, and make sure that they know who’s really bankrolling the political ads coming across their screens.

1181617159228870659.text: At a minimum, we need to demand transparency around social media to prevent our adversaries from hiding in its shadows. That includes guaranteeing that companies are identifying inauthentic user accounts and pages, and appropriately handling defamatory or synthetic content.

1181617157286879232.text:
As was made clear in 2016, we cannot expect social media companies to take adequate precautions on their own. Congress must step up and establish guardrails to protect the integrity of our democracy. 

Here’s what the Committee recommends on a bipartisan basis:

1181617155848261632.text: The Russian playbook is out in the open for other foreign and domestic adversaries to expand upon – and their techniques will only get more sophisticated. The question is, what are we going to do about it?

1181617154375991296.text: Now, with the 2020 elections on the horizon, there’s no doubt that bad actors will continue to try to weaponize the scale and reach of social media platforms to erode public confidence and foster chaos.

1181617152916373505.text: I cannot stress this enough: the Committee found that Russia’s efforts continue to this day. In fact, we found that this activity increased, rather than decreased, after Election Day 2016.

1181617151582490624.text: Russians engaged with unwitting Americans to further their reach beyond the digital realm and into real-world activities. For example, IRA operatives targeting African-Americans convinced individuals to sign petitions, share personal information, and teach self-defense courses.

1181617150068510722.text: Importantly, the Committee found the Internet Research Agency specifically targeted African-Americans more than any other group or demographic.

1181617147996450817.text: The Internet Research Agency (IRA)'s targeting of the 2016 election was intended to help Trump and hurt Clinton, but it was part of a much broader, sophisticated, and *ongoing* information warfare campaign designed to sow discord in American politics and society.

1181617146528436225.text: In 2016, Russia took advantage of our openness and innovation, exploiting American-bred social media platforms to spread disinformation, divide the public, and undermine our democracy.

1181617144611643394.text:
The Senate Intelligence Committee just released its report on Russia’s use of social media during the 2016 election. You can read the whole thing for yourself, but here are the important takeaways and recommendations:
https://t.co/GZvH0NmADf

1178707023439028224.text: This is one of those country-over-party moments. We should all be able to agree that this assault on the whistleblower process from the President and his allies needs to end immediately.

1178707021983600642.text: These allegations must be investigated in a bipartisan way. But regardless of what comes from these allegations against the President, we must protect the integrity of the whistleblower process.

1178707020985311234.text: The role of the intelligence community is to speak truth to power, and with the IC already under assault from this administration, there’s no question that this President’s latest comments will have a chilling effect on the men and women who guard our secrets and keep us safe.

1178707020012294144.text: If those are the only avenues for accountability within the intelligence community, the United States is in big trouble.

1178707019039162370.text: A future whistleblower could leak the information to the press, with no protections in place to safeguard classified information, or they could say nothing and let the wrongdoing continue. Both hurt us and help our adversaries.

1178707018116415492.text: Why? Consider the alternatives.  If someone in the intelligence community witnesses something bad that jeopardizes our national security, where can they go if they can’t report it internally?

1178707017202110470.text: The whole reason we have whistleblower protections is so intelligence professionals can report wrongdoing *without fear of retaliation.*

1178707016031883264.text: This President’s comments about “spies and treason” and “what we used to do in the old days” are totally unacceptable and will do serious damage far beyond this news cycle.

1178707013850804226.text: We are going to get to the bottom of the whistleblower’s allegations, but we cannot lose sight of how truly dangerous the President’s response to these allegations has been. https://t.co/S7F1eTZzGj
